title: Thursday evening news briefing: Essex lorry victims revealed as Chinese nationals as police get more time to question driver
text:
If you want to receive twice-daily briefings like this by email, sign up to the Front Page newsletter here and try our Audio Briefings on WhatsApp.

Essex lorry deaths: 39 migrant bodies revealed to be Chinese

The 39 people found frozen to death in a refrigerated lorry container in Essex were Chinese, police have confirmed. Officers have searched two addresses in Northern Ireland as detectives continue to question a Co Armagh lorry driver over the discovery of the migrants. Police have been given an additional 24 hours to question the driver, named locally as 25-year-old Mo Robinson. His parents are said to have flown to England to support their son, who remains in custody for questioning by Essex Police on suspicion of murder. Here is the latest. David Wood explains why Europe cannot be complacent over people smugglers and says the continent must galvanise efforts to tackle the problem.

Cabinet meets amid 'differing views' on pre-Christmas election

Boris Johnson looks set to push for an election before Christmas. As this newsletter arrives in your inbox, a meeting of the Prime Minister's political cabinet is underway but apparently there are "differing views" on whether or not to have a snap General Election. Asked about the possibility of a December poll, Tory Chairman James Cleverly said: "I don't want to be the Grinch. But the point is democracy is incredibly important and we have been prevented on discharging the duty imposed upon us." In the Commons, MPs are expected to vote on the Queen's Speech at about 5pm. As ever, the latest developments will be on The Telegraph's politics liveblog.
